revision.comment: http→https for [[Google Books]] and [[Google News]] using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox military person |name=James P. Parker |birth_date={{Birth date|df=yes|1855|9|25}} |death_date={{death date and age|df=yes|1942|1|18|1855|9|25}} |birth_place=near [[Enfield, North Carolina|Enfield]], [[North Carolina]] |death_place= |placeofburial=[[United States Naval Academy Cemetery]], [[Annapolis, Maryland|Annapolis]], [[Maryland]] |image= |caption= |nickname= |allegiance=[[United States|United States of America]] |branch=[[United States Navy]] |serviceyears=1877–1912; 1917–1919 |rank=[[File:US-O7 insignia.svg|20px]] [[Commodore (United States)|Commodore]] |commands=*{{USS|Florida|BM-9}} * {{USS|Hancock|AP-3}} * Acting [[President of the Naval War College]] |unit= |battles=*[[Spanish–American War]] * [[Philippine–American War]] * [[Banana Wars]] ** [[Santo Domingo Affair]] * [[World War I]] |awards= |relations= |laterwork= }} [[File:Retired admirals 7 August 1928.jpg|300px|right|thumb|Parker is standing second from right in this photo of retired admirals and other retirees taken at the home of [[Rear Admiral (United States)|Rear Admiral]] [[Spencer S. Wood]] at [[Jamestown, Rhode Island|Jamestown]], [[Rhode Island]], on 7 August 1928.]] [[Commodore (United States)|Commodore]] '''James Philips Parker''' (25 September 1855 – 18 January 1942) was a [[United States Navy]] [[Commissioned officer|officer]]. His career included service in the [[Spanish–American War]], the [[Philippine–American War]], and the [[Santo Domingo Affair]], and he was recalled from retirement to serve as an Acting [[President of the Naval War College]] during [[World War I]].
==Early life== Parker was born on 25 September 1855 near [[Enfield, North Carolina|Enfield]], [[North Carolina]], where his parents owned a [[plantations in the American South|plantation]]. He was the second of nine children of [[Francis Marion "Frank" Parker]] and the former Sarah Tart "Sally" Philips. His father fought on the [[Confederate States of America|Confederate]] side during the [[American Civil War]] from 1861 until forced out of service by a wound in May 1864, mostly as a [[Colonel (United States)|colonel]] commanding the 30th North Carolina [[Regiment]].<ref name="hammersly">Hamersly, p. 256.</ref><ref name="nhhc">[http://www.history.navy.mil/books/callahan/reg-usn-p.htm Naval History and Heritage Command: Officers of the Continental and U.S. Navy and Marine Corps, 1775–1900.]</ref><ref name="parker"/><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=3DPBls1U2V8C&pg=PA64&lpg=PA64&dq=James+Philips+Parker+navy&source=bl&ots=O4NYhOnB_W&sig=2_IOLNgpdItJdPA114c7mez_XJ8&hl=en&sa=X&ei=EmWEUKqSGsfK2AXF-IHoAg&ved=0CC4Q6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=James%20Philips%20Parker%20navy&f=false Fleming, Monika S., ''Edgecomb County: Along the Tar River'', Charleston, South Carolina: Arcadia, Publishing, 2003, ISBN 0-7385-2412-3, pp. 63–64.]</ref>
==Naval career== Parker entered the [[United States Naval Academy]] at [[Annapolis, Maryland|Annapolis]], [[Maryland]], as a [[cadet midshipman]] on 5 June 1873 and graduated on 18 June 1877. His first assignment was aboard the [[flagship]] of the [[South Atlantic Squadron]], the [[Propeller|screw]] [[sloop-of-war]] {{USS|Hartford|1858|6}}, from 1877 to 1879, after which he stood for his final examination and completed his studies. He then served aboard the screw sloop-of-war {{USS|Swatara|1873|6}} in the [[Asiatic Squadron]] from 1879 to 1882, and was promoted to [[Ensign (rank)|ensign]] while aboard her on 10 January 1881.<ref name="hammersly" /><ref name="nhhc" />
Parker next spent several years on [[Hydrography|hydrographic]] work. He began with duty aboard [[survey ship]]s of the [[United States Coast and Geodetic Survey]] for [[surveying]] work along the [[United States East Coast]], first aboard [[USC&GS Endeavor|USC&GS ''Endeavor'']] in 1883 and then on [[USC&GS A. D. Bache (1871)|USC&GS ''A. D. Bache'']] from 1883 to 1884. He then served aboard the U.S. Navy survey ship {{USS|Ranger|1876|6}} for additional surveying work along the [[United States West Coast]] from 1884 to 1887. Promoted to [[lieutenant, junior grade]], on 30 June 1887, his next assignment was to the Branch [[United States Hydrographic Office|Hydrographic Office]] in [[Baltimore, Maryland|Baltimore]], Maryland, from 1887 to 1890.<ref name="hammersly" /><ref name="nhhc" />
From October 1890 to October 1893, Parker was aboard the [[gunboat]] {{USS|Alert|AS-4|6}}, operating in the [[Bering Sea]] and in the Asiatic Squadron, and he was promoted to [[lieutenant]] on 25 January 1893 while aboard her. He returned to the Naval Academy to serve as an instructor from October 1893 to 1896, then reported aboard the new [[Monitor (ship)|monitor]] {{USS|Monadnock|BM-3|6}} in the [[Pacific Squadron]] in July 1896. After the outbreak of the [[Spanish–American War]] in April 1898, ''Monadnock'' was ordered to the [[Philippine Islands]] to reinforce the Asiatic Squadron there, and departed [[San Francisco, California|San Francisco]], [[California]], on 23 June 1898 for a voyage across the [[Pacific Ocean]], stopping in [[Hawaii]] in early July before arriving in [[Manila Bay]] on 16 August 1898 at the close of the war and commencing [[blockade]] duty there.<ref name="hammersly" /><ref name="nhhc" /><ref>[http://www.history.navy.mil/danfs/m13/monadnock-ii.htm ''Dictionary of American Naval Fighting Ships'': ''Monadnock'' II]</ref>
Leaving ''Monadnock'' in December 1898, Parker transferred to the gunboat {{USS|Petrel|PG-2|6}} in January 1899, seeing action against Filipino insurgents during the [[Philippine–American War]]. He left ''Petrel'' in August 1899 and was assigned to the [[hospital ship]] {{USS|Solace|AH-2|6}} in September 1899, on which he returned to the United States in October 1899. He began another tour as an instructor at the Naval Academy on 19 October 1899 and was promoted to [[Lieutenant Commander (United States)|lieutenant commander]] on 30 June 1900.<ref name="hammersly" /><ref name="nhhc" /><ref>[http://www.history.navy.mil/danfs/p5/petrel-iii.htm ''Dictionary of American Naval Fighting Ships'': ''Petrel'' III]</ref><ref>[http://www.history.navy.mil/danfs/s14/solace-i.htm ''Dictionary of American Naval Fighting Ships'': ''Solace'']</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=vcQcAQAAIAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=editions:UOM39015036626201&lr=#v=onepage&q=Warner%20Bayley&f=false ''Register of the Commissioned and Warrant Officers of the United States Navy and Marine Corps, January 1, 1902'', Washington: Government Printing Office, 1902, p. 18.]</ref>
On 11 June 1902, Parker reported for duty in the [[Atlantic Training Squadron]] aboard the [[auxiliary cruiser]] and [[troop transport]] {{USS|Panther|1889|6}}.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=0M1eMpPtLgcC&printsec=frontcover&dq=editions:UOM39015036626201&lr=#v=snippet&q=James%20Parker&f=false ''Register of the Commissioned and Warrant Officers of the United States Navy and Marine Corps, January 1, 1903'', Washington: Government Printing Office, 1903, p. 18.]</ref> By November 1903 he had transferred to the [[protected cruiser]] {{USS|Columbia|C-12|6}} in the same [[Squadron (naval)|squadron]] as her [[executive officer]]. During his tour aboard ''Columbia'', he took part in the [[Santo Domingo Affair]] when he led a landing party ashore in [[Santo Domingo]] in the [[Dominican Republic]] on 11 February 1904 to join another landing party from the protected cruiser {{USS|Newark|C-1|6}} and gunfire from the ships themselves in quelling unrest in the city.<ref>[http://freepages.military.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~cacunithistories/USS_Columbia.htm USS ''Columbia'' C-12 at ancestry.com]</ref> Detaching from ''Columbia'' in March 1905,<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=0M1eMpPtLgcC&printsec=frontcover&dq=editions:UOM39015036626201&lr=#v=snippet&q=James%20Parker&f=false ''Register of the Commissioned and Warrant Officers of the United States Navy and Marine Corps, January 1, 1905'', Washington: Government Printing Office, 1905, p. 18.]</ref> he was promoted to [[Commander (United States)|commander]] on 1 July 1905, and on 14 October 1905 he began a tour as equipment and ordnance officer at the [[Portsmouth Navy Yard]] in [[Kittery, Maine|Kittery]], [[Maine]].<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=64-2aA9c9aYC&printsec=frontcover&dq=editions:UOM39015036626201&lr=#v=onepage&q=James%20Parker&f=false ''Register of the Commissioned and Warrant Officers of the United States Navy and Marine Corps, January 1, 1906'', Washington: Government Printing Office, 1906, pp. 16–17.]</ref> On 27 August 1907, he became [[commanding officer]] of the monitor {{USS|Florida|BM-9|6}}, then in [[Reserve fleet|reserve]] and used for training activities but activated from May to July 1908 for ordnance tests of superfiring gun turrets.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=64-2aA9c9aYC&printsec=frontcover&dq=editions:UOM39015036626201&lr=#v=onepage&q=James%20Parker&f=false ''Register of the Commissioned and Warrant Officers of the United States Navy and Marine Corps, January 1, 1908'', Washington: Government Printing Office, 1908, pp. 14–15.]</ref>
Promoted to [[Captain (United States)#U.S. Navy, U.S. Coast Guard, U.S. Public Health Service, and National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|captain]] on 1 July 1909, Parker became the [[captain of the yard]] at the [[Norfolk Navy Yard]] in [[Portsmouth, Virginia|Portsmouth]], [[Virginia]], on 24 August 1909.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=l8YcAQAAIAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=editions:UOM39015036626201&lr=#v=onepage&q=James%20Parker&f=false ''Register of the Commissioned and Warrant Officers of the United States Navy and Marine Corps, January 1, 1910'', Washington: Government Printing Office, 1910, pp. 10–11.]</ref> On 27 December 1911, he took command of the [[troop transport]] {{USS|Hancock|AP-3|6}}, with additional duty on the general [[court martial]] at the [[New York Navy Yard]] in [[Brooklyn, New York|Brooklyn]], [[New York (state)|New York]].<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=occcAQAAIAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=editions:UOM39015036626201&lr=#v=onepage&q=James%20Parker&f=false ''Register of the Commissioned and Warrant Officers of the United States Navy and Marine Corps, January 1, 1912'', Washington: Government Printing Office, 1912, p. 10.]</ref>
Parker retired from the Navy as a [[Commodore (United States)|commodore]] on 30 June 1912.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=9ZSlyS7MrzAC&printsec=frontcover&dq=editions:UOM39015036626201&lr=#v=onepage&q=James%20Parker&f=false ''Register of the Commissioned and Warrant Officers of the United States Navy and Marine Corps, January 1, 1915'', Washington: Government Printing Office, 1915, p. 194.]</ref>
After the United States entered [[World War I]] in April 1917, Parker was recalled to active duty. He served as acting [[President of the Naval War College|president]] of the [[Naval War College]] in [[Newport, Rhode Island|Newport]], [[Rhode Island]], from 21 November 1917 to 17 March 1919, the second of three acting presidents to oversee the college while its academic activities were shut down for the war between April 1917 and April 1919.<ref>Jackson, Duvall, and Rhoades, pp. 14–15.</ref>
==Personal life== Parker was married to the former Mary McPherson (29 August 1862 – 16 July 1937).<ref name="parker">[http://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=75973204 Find-A-Grave Memorial: James Philips Parker (1855–1942)]</ref><ref name="parker2">[http://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=75973182 Find-A-Grave Memorial: Mary McPherson Parker (1862–1937)]</ref>
==Death== Parker died on 18 January 1942 and is buried with his wife at the [[United States Naval Academy Cemetery]] in Annapolis, Maryland.<ref name="parker" /><ref name="parker2" />
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==References== * [http://www.history.navy.mil/books/callahan/reg-usn-p.htm Naval History and Heritage Command: Officers of the Continental and U.S. Navy and Marine Corps, 1775–1900.] * [https://books.google.com/books?id=c70_AAAAYAAJ&pg=PA509&lpg=PA509&dq=raymond+p.+rodgers+Hamersly&source=bl&ots=yJRR8UqzLO&sig=BQ-fk5rmI33CGsD9lESD9yzgqCE&hl=en&sa=X&ei=xcW6T-fLIqnq2AWpveXRCQ&sqi=2&ved=0CFYQ6AEwBg#v=onepage&q&f=false Hamersly, Lewis Randolph. ''The Records of Living Officers of the U.S. Navy and Marine Corps, Seventh Edition'', New York: L. R. Hamersly Company, 1902.] * Jackson, John E., Jondavid Duvall, and Kimberly Rhoades, eds. ''Naval War College Illustrated History and Guide'', Second Edition. Washington, D.C.: Government Printing Office, 2010. ISBN 978-1-884733-72-7, ISBN 1-884733-72-7. * [http://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=75973204 Find-A-Grave Memorial: James Philips Parker (1855–1942)] * [http://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=75973182 Find-A-Grave Memorial: Mary McPherson Parker (1862–1937)]
==External links== * [http://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=75973204 Photograph of the grave of James Philips Parker and Mary McPherson Parker at Find-A-Grave] * [http://www.usna.edu/cemetery/PDF%20Files/Section%201/153B-%20Parker,%20J.%20P.pdf Photographs of the grave of James Philips Parker and Mary McPherson Parker at United States Naval Academy Cemetery and Columbarium site]
